perturbation.original_text: Upon termination of this Agreement, all rights and duties of the parties hereunder shall cease except: Company shall be obliged to pay, within thirty (30) days after receipt of Consultant's final statement, all amounts owing to Consultant for unpaid Services completed by Consultant and related expenses, if any, in accordance with the provisions of Section 1 hereof, and Sections 2, 3, S(c), 6, 7, 8 and 10 shall survive termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon termination of this Agreement, all rights and duties of the parties hereunder shall cease except: Company shall be obliged to pay, within sixty (60) days after receipt of Consultant's final statement, all amounts owing to Consultant for unpaid Services completed by Consultant and related expenses, if any, in accordance with the provisions of Section 1 hereof, and Sections 2, 3, S(c), 6, 7, 8 and 10 shall survive termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment timeframe from 30 to 60 days after the final statement could violate Texas Payday Law, which requires prompt payment of final wages.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Labor Code § 61.051 states that an employer must pay an employee who is terminated all wages due by the sixth day after the date of termination. The modified clause extends the payment period to 60 days, directly conflicting with this provision for prompt payment of final wages.

perturbation.original_text: 11. Background Check and Authorization to Work. This offer of employment is contingent on the Company's completion of a satisfactory background check of you. Please note that because of employer regulations adopted in the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, within three (3) business days of starting your new position you will need to present documentation demonstrating that you have authorization to work in the United States. If you have questions about this requirement, which applies to U.S. citizens and non-U.S. citizens alike, please let us know.
perturbation.changed_text: 11. Background Check and Authorization to Work. This offer of employment is contingent on the Company's completion of a satisfactory background check of you. Please note that because of employer regulations adopted in the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, you will need to present documentation demonstrating that you have authorization to work in the United States at any time during your contract.
perturbation.explanation: The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 sets a specific timeframe for completing the I-9 form and verifying work authorization. Removing the "within three (3) business days of starting your new position" timeframe and replacing it with 'at any time during your contract' contradicts the Act's requirements for timely verification.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986
perturbation.law_explanation: 8 U.S. Code § 1324a(b) requires employers to verify an employee's eligibility to work in the United States within a specific timeframe by completing Form I-9. The modified clause's removal of the deadline and statement to complete it at any time violates the specified timeframe requirement, leading to non-compliance with federal law.

perturbation.original_text: Consultants shall be given written notice of any adjustments to compensation at least fourteen (14) days prior to adjustments becoming effective.
perturbation.changed_text: Consultants shall be given written notice of any adjustments to compensation at least seven (7) days prior to adjustments becoming effective.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for compensation adjustments to seven days could violate state laws requiring longer notice periods for changes in pay. Since the contract is in Texas, we should see if there is a contradiction with that.
perturbation.law_explanation: While Texas law does not specifically mandate a minimum notice period for wage changes for independent contractors, reducing the notice period to seven days could be deemed unreasonable or exploitative, particularly if the changes significantly impact the consultant's earnings. A court could find that such a short notice period violates principles of good faith and fair dealing, especially in the context of ongoing service provision.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: "Day" means a calendar day. (3) "Employee" means an individual who is employed by an employer for compensation. The term does not include: (A) a person related to the employer or the employer's spouse within the first or second degree by consanguinity or affinity, as determined under Chapter 573 , Government Code; or (B) an independent contractor. (4) "Employer" means a person who: (A) employs one or more employees; or (B) acts directly or indirectly in the interests of an employer in relation to an employee. (5) "Employment" means any service, including service in interstate commerce, that is performed for wages or under a contract of hire, whether written or oral or express or implied. The term does not include any service performed by an individual for wages if it is shown that the individual is free from control or direction in the performance of the service, both under any contract of service and in fact. (6) "Mail" means to deposit for mailing with the United States Postal Service. (6-a) "Payroll card account" means an account that is directly or indirectly established by an employer into which each participating employee's wages, salary, or other form of compensation is deposited on a recurring basis and for which the employee receives a payroll card to access the funds in the account. (7) "Wages" means compensation owed by an employer for: (A) labor or services rendered by an employee, whether computed on a time, task, piece, commission, or other basis; and (B) vacation pay, holiday pay, sick leave pay, parental leave pay, or severance pay owed to an employee under a written agreement with the employer or under a written policy of the employer.
